title: Find Resistance of Resistor in Circuit

content.question:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students are to experimentally determine the resistance <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resistor in a circuit as shown. The other components of the circuit are a capacitor with capacitance <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, a battery with potential difference <math alttext="script uppercase E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and switch S. In addition, there are several different capacitors that are available for the students to use. The capacitors are initially uncharged. The students are expected to collect data as the capacitor is charging and then find the resistance <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resistor through graphical analysis. The students have access to equipment typically found in a high school physics lab but must use a setup similar to the one shown above.

(a) Clearly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

frqParts.text:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students are to experimentally determine the resistance <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resistor in a circuit as shown. The other components of the circuit are a capacitor with capacitance <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, a battery with potential difference <math alttext="script uppercase E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and switch S. In addition, there are several different capacitors that are available for the students to use. The capacitors are initially uncharged. The students are expected to collect data as the capacitor is charging and then find the resistance <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resistor through graphical analysis. The students have access to equipment typically found in a high school physics lab but must use a setup similar to the one shown above.

(a) Clearly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Describe the procedure a student would use to collect data that would allow the student to determine the resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resistor. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a) above.

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the horizontal and vertical axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resistor?

(d) Describe the process by which the students would use the graph described in part (c) to determine the resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resistor. Include the relevant feature of the graph that would be used and how it would be used to determine the resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resistor.

(e) After completing their calculations, the students find that their calculated value for the resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resistor is more than the expected resistance of the resistor. Explain one experimental factor that may account for this difference and justify your answer.

skill.text: 3.A: Create experimental procedures that are appropriate for a given scientific question.
